Issues.Title: Computed function does not re-compute when dependency change
Issues.Body: ### Version 2.6.10 ### Reproduction link [https://codepen.io/rellect/pen/EzvrOz?editors=1011](https://codepen.io/rellect/pen/EzvrOz?editors=1011) ### Steps to reproduce - Open the repro link - Click the Toggle button - See that the value changes but the dynamic component does not ### What is expected? Dynamic component should change when the data property changes. ### What is actually happening? The computed property does not react when the data property changes. --- What I'm trying to do is a to import a component dynamically based on a reactive data property. Something similar to the following: ``` ``` For some reason `stepComp` won't re-compute when `step` is changed. It's not a big issue and I can workaround it, but still wonder if this is a bug or by design.

Issues.Title: Directive for both v-bind and v-on
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
I have several cases of components with different views, the children of these components are almost the same, but have some key differences, I want my code to be DRY and give the implementation in a base Component 

Imagine i have a component with this template:
```html
<template>
  <component is="myView" :textOptions="textOptions" />
</template>
```
Whatever view is chosen, there's always a text component inside that uses these textOptions like so:
```html
<TextComponent v-bind="textOptions.props" v-on="textOptions.listeners" :otherProps=" 'other' " />
```


### What does the proposed API look like?
I propose a new directive (which I'm calling v-all for now)
```html
 <TextComponent v-all="textOptions" />
```

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Directive for both v-bind and v-on" (#10052)

Issues.Title: Memory leak (DOM) when use select element
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.10

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/gr8den/vue-select-memory-leak/blob/master/vue-select-memory-leak.html](https://github.com/gr8den/vue-select-memory-leak/blob/master/vue-select-memory-leak.html)







### Steps to reproduce
1. Open vue-select-memory-leak.html from repo (I use Google Chrome 74.0.3729.157)
2. Open Chrome DevTools on this page
3. Go to page Performance, enable Memory checkbox
4. Start Record, click Collect garbage
5. Click Toggle button multiple times (I clicking 50 seconds, multiple times in second)
6. Click Collect garbage, click Stop record
7. See nodes leak on Memory chart - count of nodes not decreased after Collecting garbage (in my case nodes increased from 50 to ~2500)

### What is expected?
No memory leak - Count of nodes must be decrease after force collect garbage

### What is actually happening?
Have memory leak (DOM)

---
I try replace "select" element to "input" element and after it DOM nodes cleaned right (no leak). Also I try add 10000 options to select, browser still not clean nodes, but use a lot of RAM

Issues.Title: Unexpected behaviour when using v-on:input and v-bind:value instead of v-model.
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.10

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/9mj0nakc/2/](https://jsfiddle.net/9mj0nakc/2/)

### Steps to reproduce
Type in each input

### What is expected?
Input box 2 to be bound to variable test.b

### What is actually happening?
It doesn't behave like v-model

---
On this page:
https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/components.html#Using-v-model-on-Components

It says that
`<input v-model="searchText">`

does the same thing as:
```
<input
  v-bind:value="searchText"
  v-on:input="searchText = $event.target.value"
>
```

But it appears this is not true when referencing a property of a variable, e.g. var['prop'].

If you do not think this is a problem, I would like to at least understand:
- what is special/different about v-model vs the second method that makes it work properly and listen to changes on the prop when the on&bind combination doesn't seem to listen to changes.
- and how I could make on&bind it work similarly to v-model.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Unexpected behaviour when using v-on:input and v-bind:value instead of v-model." (#10047)

Issues.Title: Undocumented breaking change of checkbox/radio in 2.6.0
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.0

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/goblinlord/k64bx8gp/9/](https://jsfiddle.net/goblinlord/k64bx8gp/9/)







### Steps to reproduce
1. Create an element with `type` attribute set to either `checkbox` or `radio`.
2. Call `preventDefault` on the `click` event (or just set `@click.prevent`)
3. Set the `checked` value synchronously to a different value

### What is expected?
New value that is set should be reflected in the rendered markup.

### What is actually happening?
The result of the value changing is not reflected in the in the rendered state even though the value is actually changed based on what is shown in Vue dev tools.

---
This worked prior to `2.6.0` and I can not find any documentation indicating the behavior changed or why it would change.  In the reproduction link you can comment out the `2.6.0` version and uncomment the line above it with `2.5.22`.  On `2.5.22` it works as expected.

I have been using this previously when wrapping an input with a styled alternative with additional markup/styling.  The purpose of having `preventDefault` is to allow the decision of the value change to be made in a location other than the checkbox itself.  For example, we could easily display a dialog box when the user clicks this and then when it is closed set the state based on the response.  Removing `preventDefault` causes the checkbox to toggle.  If this happens but we want to wait until a later time to set the state, the desired state is not reflected properly until that time.  Some cases, no async work is done and it is desirable to change state immediately.  In those cases, a simple `v-model` can be used with the same exact component.

A dialog box is just one example, I also have cases where there is an network call before the actual state is changed.  (one style is a toggle slider for example but i have other styled inputs as well)

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Undocumented breaking change of checkbox/radio in 2.6.0" (#10045)

Issues.Title: Using transition-group with SVG does not give smooth transition
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.22

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/arthurmcgregor/41wz7nLr/24/](https://jsfiddle.net/arthurmcgregor/41wz7nLr/24/)







### Steps to reproduce
Open the JS Fiddle. Click between the home, all, air buttons (with at least 2s pause between each click)

### What is expected?
The circles should move smoothly from one position to another

### What is actually happening?
The circles jump about halfway to their new position, then move smoothly the rest of the way

---
I have tried this with fixed position divs instead of using SVG and the animation is smooth (however, the scaling is terrible so would like to avoid that!)

Although my actual project is runinng v 2.5.22, I assume the JSFiddle is the latest version and the bug is reproduced there.

There are around 250 circles but the same bug happens with fewer circles. eg `v-for="bubble of bubbles.slice(0,10)"`

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Documentation not clear concerning directive "inserted" hooks
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.10

### Reproduction link
[https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/custom-directive.html#Hook-Functions](https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/custom-directive.html#Hook-Functions)

### Steps to reproduce
Read the documentation about custom directive's and the inserted hook.

### What is expected?
To know about the hook's moment in the directive's lifecycle.

### What is actually happening?
The documentation mentions : 
> "inserted: called when the bound element has been inserted into its parent node (this only guarantees parent node presence, not necessarily in-document)."

The current sentence doesn't provide reliable information about the conditions needed for the the directive to be or not to be attached to the current document at the time of inserted hook call.

---
My guess is that it depends on the context's vnode and the directive's vnode node being synchronously rendered (or not), but I've only clues.

If that's the case, it would be nice to have an actual "flatten" way to handle it, like an additional hook or a different lifecycle.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Documentation not clear concerning directive "inserted" hooks" (#10042)

Issues.Title: Nested transition behavior inconsistent at mount/unmount
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.10

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/ae82rfnv/](https://jsfiddle.net/ae82rfnv/)

### Steps to reproduce
While operating, carefully notice of the transitions

Working flow
1. tick first box (parent transition plays)
2. tick second box (child transition plays)
3. untick second box (child transition plays)
4. untick first box (parent transition plays)

Broken flow n¬∞1
1. tick first box (parent transition plays)
2. tick second box (child transition plays)
3. untick first box (only parent transition plays)

Broken flow n¬∞2
1. tick second box (nothing happens)
2. tick first box (the 2 transitions play in sync)
3. untick first box (only parent transition plays)

### What is expected?
While unmounting, a transition should search for nested transition and operates in sequence carefully, running children transition first, then playing its own transition before unmounting, so all children transition could run their "leave" transition carefully.

### What is actually happening?
Only the parent transiton runs, ignoring the children transition.

---
I understand why it does what it does as is, and it makes sense from mounting point of view ; where the logic fails is in the "final effect" : while the 2 transitions (parent and child) play correctly when mounting, it doesn't run "the opposite way/backwards" when unmounting.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nested transition behavior inconsistent at mount/unmount" (#10030)

Issues.Title: Triggering a listener of a functional component breaks reactivity in Safari 12.1, if iframe is on the page
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.10

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/ebgj6fra/2/](https://jsfiddle.net/ebgj6fra/2/)







### Steps to reproduce
- Access the fiddle
- click the "change" button

### What is expected?
*Hello world!* should change to *tada!*

### What is actually happening?
In latest Safari (12.1) on Mac OS, nothing happens, but it works as expected in other browsers.

---
Removing the `iframe` from the page makes the issue go away, as seen here: https://jsfiddle.net/ebgj6fra/3/

Seems like maybe there's a difference in how/when the latest Safari runs the `flushCallbacks`.

Conditionally rendering the iframe (`v-if="myExpression !== null`), triggering the listener inside a `setTimeout` or calling `$forceUpdate` circumvents the issue.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: (fix #2724): Fix active links when parent link redirects to child
Issues.Body:
This PR provides a fix to the issue #2724 .

Reproduction link

https://jsfiddle.net/posva/fj7ywzxv/

Whenever a parent node has a redirect option, the router.resolve method will return the redirected route when given the parent location as argument. This creates a problem when comparing a link route with the current route as the link route will be the route of the redirected component and not the route of the parent component...
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "(fix #2724): Fix active links when parent link redirects to child" (#2772)

Issues.Title: (fix #2607): Fix router.back in abstract mode when 2 consecutive same routes appear in history stack
Issues.Body:
This PR provides a fix to the issue #2607.

Reproduction link

https://jsfiddle.net/Rocka/bhu5vkn8/3/

In abstract mode, if you try to navigate through your history with the same routes appearing consecutively in your stack history, the history index remains unchanged.

In History or Hash mode, this issue does not appear because history navigation is handled by the browser and not by vue-router. In all modes, we do not want to re-render a page if the current route and the next route are identical. However, in the case of abstract mode, we still need to update the history index whenever the current and next routes are the same since AbstractHistory handles its own history stack.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "(fix #2607): Fix router.back in abstract mode when 2 consecutive same routes appear in history stack" (#2771)

Issues.Title: Not being directed to default child route when using router-link
Issues.Body:
Example router config:
```
{
		path: '/project',
		name: 'Project Home',
		component: () => import('src/App.vue'),
		children: [
			{
				path: '',
				component: () => import('src/pages/ProjectHomePage.vue'),
			},
```

Example router-link:
```
<router-link :to="{ name: route.name, params: route.params }">
	{{ route.name }}
</router-link>
```

The first child of named **Project Home** route is the default child.  When clicking on the router-link, I'm brought to the App.vue component instead of being redirected to the ProjectHomePage.vue component... is there a way to get to the ProjectHomePage.vue (default child) component without using a redirect?

Oddly enough, on refresh of that URL, I am redirected to the ProjectHomePage component
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Not being directed to default child route when using router-link" (#2769)

Issues.Title: Creating a type declaration for `next`
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
At the moment there is a type definition for `NavigationGuard` in `router.d.ts`. This works nicely. Within that, the `next` argument is a function that accepts a union of different types as argument.

```ts
next: (to?: RawLocation | false | ((vm: V) => any) | void) => void
```

I think it'd be neat to easily use this just like the `Route` interface declaration in, for example, a components navigation guard.

### What does the proposed API look like?
Export a type definition maybe called `NavigationGuardCallback` in `router.d.ts`.

```ts
export type NavigationGuardCallback = (to?: RawLocation | false | ((vm: V) => any) | void) => void;

export type NavigationGuard<V extends Vue = Vue> = (
  to: Route,
  from: Route,
  next: NavigationGuardCallback
) => any;
```

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Creating a type declaration for `next`" (#2758)

### Version

### Reproduction link

### Steps to reproduce
- Create a new app
- Add a lazy loaded route named 'myRoute'
- Build it
- Check that you have a `myRoute.js` file in your build folder
- Deploy it to an apache server after following the `.htaccess` recommandation in the vue-router docs

```
Options -MultiViews
RewriteEngine On
RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} !-f
```

Issues.Title: Is path-to-regexp fully supported by vue-router?
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.3

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/3qzr50oo46](https://codesandbox.io/s/3qzr50oo46)


### Steps to reproduce
Click on each link, and see that is redirect to the 'not found' route instead the 'hello' route.


### What is expected?
This path-to-regexp `/@(:lng,:lat,:zoom z)?(/p/:parcels)?(/c/:cart)?` works on [express-route-tester](https://forbeslindesay.github.io/express-route-tester/) for these paths:

`/@43.21,5.67,9z/p/12345/c/9876`  
`/@43.21,5.67,9z/p/12345`  
`/@43.21,5.67,9z`  
`/@/p/12345/c/9876`  
`/@/p/12345`  
`/@/c/9876`  
`/@`  

So it should works on `vue-router`.

### What is actually happening?
`vue-router` doesn't understand it...

---
Hello, 

I've write this quite complex **path-to-regexp**:
```
/@(:lng,:lat,:zoom z)?(/p/:parcels)?(/c/:cart)?
```

Because I need a component who support all these routes:
`/@43.21,5.67,9z/p/12345/c/9876`  
`/@43.21,5.67,9z/p/12345`  
`/@43.21,5.67,9z`  
`/@/p/12345/c/9876`  
`/@/p/12345`  
`/@/c/9876`  
`/@`  

To get (`lng`, `lat`, `zoom`), `parcels` and `cart` params individually

I've tested my regex an all these paths on the **route-tester** recommended by [path-to-regexp](https://github.com/pillarjs/path-to-regexp), and everything works as excepted:
https://forbeslindesay.github.io/express-route-tester/

But on `vue-router`, it doesn't work at all...

And I can't find any explanation on [vue-router docs](https://router.vuejs.org/guide/essentials/dynamic-matching.html#advanced-matching-patterns)

**Here is a codesandbox to reproduce the case:**
https://3qzr50oo46.codesandbox.io/home

Thanks for your help!

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Is path-to-regexp fully supported by vue-router?" (#2747)

Issues.Title: Is path-to-regexp fully supported by vue-router?

Hello, 

I've write this quite complex **path-to-regexp**:


Because I need a component who support all these routes:

`/@43.21,5.67,9z`

`/@/p/12345`
`/@/c/9876`
`/@`

To get (`lng`, `lat`, `zoom`), `parcels` and `cart` params individually

I've tested my regex an all these paths on the **route-tester** recommended by [path-to-regexp](https://github.com/pillarjs/path-to-regexp), and everything works as excepted:
https://forbeslindesay.github.io/express-route-tester/

But on `vue-router`, it doesn't work at all...

And I can't find any explanation on [vue-router docs](https://router.vuejs.org/guide/essentials/dynamic-matching.html#advanced-matching-patterns)

Issues.Title: MapGetters not working for modules with namespaced=true in vuex
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.1.1

### Reproduction link
[https://gitlab.com/Xambey/large](https://gitlab.com/Xambey/large)







### Steps to reproduce
1) Run the application.
2) Open console in web browser (or vue extensions)
3) Catch the error in the log (ChildA.vue: 14 )

"Property or method "score" is not defined on the instance but referenced during render. Make sure that this property is reactive, either in the data option, or for class-based components, by initializing the property"

found in

---> <ChildA> at src/components/ChildA.vue
       <Parent> at src/components/Parent.vue
         <App> at src/App.vue
           <Root>


### What is expected?
The getter 'score'  is created in my component. (this.$store.getters['scoreBoard/score'] -> this.score)



### What is actually happening?
Getter no mapped, vue google chrome extension show what state existed https://i.imgur.com/QKB7Wqm.png

---
```
computed: {
    ...mapGetters([
      'scoreBoard/score' // Not found when /scoreBoard/score is existed. 
    ])
  }
```
if you do this, then everything works (or namespaced = false): 
```
computed: {
    ...mapGetters({
      score: 'scoreBoard/score'
    })
  }
```
<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Dynamic namespaces in binding helpers (mapState, ‚Ä¶)
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
With this feature we can use a prop for setting a namespace :

`...mapState(this.namespace, ['filter'])`

Actually we got the error :

> Cannot read property 'namespace' of undefined

In my app I am dynamically registering store modules with generated on the fly namespaces. And I am passing the namespace as component properties.

Right now I have to do :

```
filter() { // more verbose but working
      return this.$store.state[this.namespace].filter
}
```

which is more verbose.


related stackoverflow issue : https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55927452/vuex-dynamic-namespaces-in-binding-helpers-mapstate


### What does the proposed API look like?
...mapState(this.namespace, ['filter'])

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: makeLocalGetters performance hit on ssr
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.1.0

### Reproduction link
[https://codepen.io/frankcs/pen/NmOLNX](https://codepen.io/frankcs/pen/NmOLNX)







### Steps to reproduce
Using vuex on ssr following the ssr guide. I have created an application with a large number of components and modules and therefore a large number of namespaced getters. Every time such a getter is invoked the makeLocalGetters function is called iterating trough all the getters in the store just to create the gettersProxy object. This is overkill for ssr performance and is being flagged as a CPU consuming process in the node profiler. 
I have managed to double the number of requests per second my ssr app can handle just by using memoization on the gettersProxy object creation. I think this is really impacting performance.

### What is expected?
Namespaced getters invokation not to be inefficient with large numbers of getters/modules

### What is actually happening?
A lot of hits to makeLocalGetters making performance go down

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "makeLocalGetters performance hit on ssr" (#1539)

Issues.Body:

Let the IDE prompt you correctly.

### What does the proposed API look like?
Submodule calls can be called like js modules.
For example: this.$store.module.state
The calling method of the js module allows the IDE to recognize it correctly.

Issues.Title: Unused callback parameter in registerAction method causing trouble when testing mapActions
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/blob/4c0d0ae0abcd48f1df2c0c263402a94a214168b2/src/store.js#L434](https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/blob/4c0d0ae0abcd48f1df2c0c263402a94a214168b2/src/store.js#L434)







### Steps to reproduce
1. Create a component with method using mapActions
2. Test call of the method
3. Notice that the store action is called with 3 parameters: the store, the payload, and a unused callback always set to undefined.

### What is expected?
The action must be called with only the 2 first parameters.

### What is actually happening?
The action is called with a third parameters (cb) set to undefined.

---
I think this is an error. I don't see where it can be used.
I did not do a JSFiddle but linked you directly to the line where the potentially unused callback is.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Unused callback parameter in registerAction method causing trouble when testing mapActions" (#1526)
